---
title: "Labeling"
---

<div id="labeling" class="section level1">
<h1>Labeling</h1>
<p>It is very important when making graphs to be able to label features. We will look at various ways in which we can label our graphics now.</p>
<div id="labeling-the-axes" class="section level2">
<h2>Labeling the Axes</h2>
<p>We can add a lot of features to the axes but for now we will just change labels. We use <code>xlab</code> and <code>ylab</code> for this, if we set them to <code>NULL</code> we have blank axes labels. For example we can make a graph based on departure delay and speed:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>ggplot(data, aes(dep_delay, distance/air_time*60)) +
    geom_point(alpha = 1 / 3) +
    xlab(&quot;Departure Delay (minutes)&quot;) +
    ylab(&quot;Speed (MPH)&quot;)</code></pre>
<p>We can see that the <code>xlab()</code> and the <code>ylab()</code> functions are just added in as layers. They produce the graph below.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="other-text-labels" class="section level2">
<h2>Other Text Labels</h2>
<p>Aside from labeling the axes, many times we want to add other text into our graphics. <code>geom_text</code> will allow a user to add text to a graph. We simply add <code>geom_text()</code> as a layer and this layer has the following options:</p>
<ul>
<li>the option <code>family</code> allows a user to specify font.</li>
<li>the option <code>fontface</code> allows a user to specify: plain, bold or italic.</li>
<li><code>hjust, vjust</code> allows a user to specify location of the text.</li>
<li><code>size</code> allows the user to adjust the size of a graph.</li>
</ul>
<div id="font-families" class="section level3">
<h3>Font Families</h3>
<p>We will first look at the different font styles that could be used with <code>geom_text()</code> using the <code>family</code> option. These 3 fonts work with every type of graph in ggplot:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df &lt;- data.frame(x = 1, y = 3:1, family = c(&quot;sans&quot;, &quot;serif&quot;, &quot;mono&quot;))
ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
geom_text(aes(label = family, family = family))</code></pre>
<p>As you can see below we now have three different labels with three different font types.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="font-face-styles" class="section level3">
<h3>Font Face Styles</h3>
<p>Many times we also wish to add other attributes to our text. The font face allows for plain text, <strong>bold text</strong>, and <em>italic text</em>.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df &lt;- data.frame(x = 1, y = 3:1, face = c(&quot;plain&quot;, &quot;bold&quot;, &quot;italic&quot;))
ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
geom_text(aes(label = face, fontface = face))</code></pre>
<p>Once again, <code>geom_text()</code> is a layer and this time we use the text labels of:</p>
<ul>
<li>plain</li>
<li>bold</li>
<li>italic</li>
</ul>
<p>Then we specify that each of these has the same face as their name.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
</div>
<div id="nudge-to-label-existing-points" class="section level2">
<h2>Nudge to label existing points</h2>
<p>The nudge allows us to move the text horizontally or vertically to label points. If we did not do this, our text would lie directly on top of the point. We use <code>nudge_x</code> and <code>nudge_y</code> in order to move the text in the <code>x</code> and <code>y</code> direction respectively.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df &lt;- data.frame(trt = c(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;, &quot;c&quot;), resp = c(1.2, 3.4, 2.5))
ggplot(df, aes(resp, trt)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_text(aes(label = paste0(&quot;(&quot;, resp, &quot;)&quot;)), nudge_y = -0.25) +
    xlim(1, 3.6)</code></pre>
<p>The code above uses the <code>paste</code> command which takes information and combines it together. In this example the paste will take the values of <code>resp</code> and place them inside parenthesis. Then we use <code>nudge_y-0.25</code> to move the label below the point and the addition of <code>xlim(1,3.6)</code> is a layer that tells us what the x-axis should extend to and from:</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="labels-rather-than-a-legend" class="section level2">
<h2>Labels Rather than a Legend</h2>
<p>One other common feature of a graph can be to use labeling rather than a legend. The code is a bit more advanced for this phase, below you can see that we have done a few different things.</p>
<ol style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>We created 2 plots <code>p1</code> and <code>p2</code>.</li>
<li><code>p2</code> uses <code>geom_dl()</code> to add labels as a legend</li>
<li><code>grid.arrange()</code> allows us to place the graphs side by side.</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>library(directlabels)
library(gridExtra)
p1 = ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = class)) +
    geom_point()
p2 = ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = class)) +
    geom_point(show.legend = FALSE) +
    geom_dl(aes(label = class), method = &quot;smart.grid&quot;)
grid.arrange(p1,p2, ncol=2)</code></pre>
<p>What you will see happen is the graph on the left, <code>p1</code>, will have the traditional legend that is displayed when you color by a categorical variable. Then the graph on the right <code>p2</code> will place those same labels throughout the plot with the particular color that that label is.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
</div>




</div>
